Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2014 06:26PM MBLizzy wrote: I am claustrophobic also.  I had never had an MRI before (refused one once/unrelated to bc).  I took something for my nerves before hand (I have never taken anything before for anxiety).  I was also on my stomach with my hands rasied above my head.  I took about an hour.  The first time I was slide in the machine, I freaked out a bit and made them pull me out.  The nurses tried to reassureme and said it was my choice to try again.  I agreed to try again, and I did fine.  They said sometimes being pulled out once gives enough reassurance to get through the test.
Posts.Title: Please describe your breast MRI CeciliaVera Trvler

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2013 04:56PM MBLizzy wrote: Hi Sheila I too was diagnosed with ilc. I went in for my annual mammo and they noted micro classifications, had a biopsy and found ilc in my left breast. At that point it looked small and thought i would need a lumpectomy. I went for an mri and a 3.7 cm tumor was found as well as what look like a 5+ cm tumor. Neither showed on mammo or u/s. the right breast look fine and was told my choice of bmx or uni- but after the mammo missing the tumors, i decided on a bmx. After the BMX, turns out the 5+cm tumor was 4 smaller ilc tumors and my my lymph nodes were negative. Also, the right breast had a small ilc tumor. I will not be needing chemo or rads (Low risk on mammaprint). Will be on tamoxifen for 5 years, starting next week. The ilc was probably growing for several years.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2013 01:41PM MBLizzy wrote: I had 60 cc done at surgury on each side. My first post op with the PS was 4 days after surgury- no fills ( the was no way- everything hurt too much). My next appt with the PS was 13 days after surgury and he removed the drains and filled with another 60cc each side. I was uncomfortable for at least the next 3-4 days. I feel really good right now (almost 3weeks post surgury). Last night I could sleep on one side, but not the left, the cancer side(I am a side sleeper so it was really nice). I meet with the PS on thrus And I expect another fill. I am thin and before bc was barely a B cup. Do not want to go any bigger. HTH
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2013 07:00PM MBLizzy wrote: Well it is my turn for surgury tomorrow. Reading everyone's posts has been very helpful. Thank you! I am a very quiet person so I don"t post much, but I do check this board a lot and I will give everyone an update as soon as I can after surgury. My best to all.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 26, 2013 12:30PM MBLizzy wrote: Got my pathology report. No positive nodes (well one had a sliver but too small to be technically positive)! I was looking at a 5 cm tumor per mri ( nothing showed on mammo or us), but it was 4 smaller, unconnected tumors - all ilc. I am staged at IIa, which is much better than anticipated. So glad I did the right side too - a small ilc tumor was also found in my non cancer breast, along with dcis. The prophylactic mx was clearly the right call. Sending out good thought to everyone!
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2013 09:44PM MBLizzy wrote: Bella, I do have full use of both arms and full range of motion ( or close to it) but i am still very carefull with my left arm (cancer side) and don't do a lot of things ( like lift anything slightly heavy and don't make quick movements with my left arm). I am tight under my arm where they took the nodes but if I streatch it almost disappears. Each day the tightness seems a bit better. It will be 5 weeks tomorrow since my surgury.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2013 06:22PM MBLizzy wrote: I'll give a second recommendation for the champion seamless bra from target. Love it. I saw it last week and thought it might work. It is very comfy and I can step into it. I have since bought 2 more. I use it both for everyday and for working out (just start back at the gym). I still prefer to sleep in a loose camisole.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2013 01:22PM MBLizzy wrote: julieped Sometimes it feels good and sometimes not. Right after surgury there was no way I could wear any type of compression bra. I tried. Now, if I am being more active ( been walking a lot) I feel better with a little compression, at night it is a little uncomfortable, so i don't sleep with a bra. The rest of the time is mixed. I am starting to spend more and more of my non-active non-sleeping time with the target bra. It is light compression not like a traditional jog bra which is still not comfortable for me yet.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2013 08:59PM MBLizzy wrote: Just got back from the ps and my last fill. i am now up to 300 cc each side. The fills have been 60cc each week. I am on the smaller side (5ft 61/2ins - 120 lbs) and am going for my nearly b cup that I had pre bc. We are scheduling the exchange for earlier December! I started tamoxifen last Thursday, and the last 2 days I have been nauseous and had a constant mild headache but today I am feeling good - hope it lasts. The hot flashes have been mostly mild - Good thoughts to all.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Nov 1, 2013 10:20PM MBLizzy wrote: Sandra, my exchange is also scheduled for Dec 6th!! I have been extremely lucky with almost no complications with my TE. I am going for a b cup (or less) - my size pre BC was barely a b cup and I enjoyed being small chested (I am thin/slim). I am filled only to 300cc each side, but I was still uncomfortable (had some pain) the night and next day after each fill. I will be having anatomical Mentor implants which will be a tad larger than the TE. My experience with the TE hasn't been awful but I will be very glad to get rid of them. In the last week or so there are times I forget they are there (which is amazing to me) but it doesn't last too long.

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2013 11:54PM MBLizzy wrote: I am scheduled for September 19th for a BMX with TE. A long wait, but the 2 onchologist I talked with were ok with waiting. I am going to take at least a week off from work before the surgery I find it very difficult to concentrate at work, with all the worrying and lack of sleep. I am 50, work full-time and have 2 kids in grade school.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 04:14AM MBLizzy wrote: My surgury went well. The injections for the sentenial dissection before surgury were not painful for me (I was lucky). They found 6 sentenial nodes on my left side. The bs only took 2 - she did not want on take all 6. The 2 came back clean, but i won't have the final report until next week. I went home yesterday (so only stayed over the one night). I am able to move around fairly easily. I am taking norco (1 tab every 4 hrs) but may switch to Tylenol during the day tomorrow to see how that goes. I have 2 drains - one on each side. The side were they took the nodes is draining much more than the other. The TE are not exactly comfortable, but I can't complain too much. Wishing the upcoming surgeries all the best.
Posts.Title: September 2013 surgery hobbesla4 Katlebbie
